segment.source: In many operating systems, the most common method to authenticate a user's identity is to use a secret passphrase or password.
segment.target: In many operating systems, the most common method to authenticate a user's identity is to use a secret passphrase or password.

segment.source: A secure network environment requires all users to use strong passwords, which have at least eight characters and include a combination of letters, numbers, and symbols.
segment.target: A secure network environment requires all users to use strong passwords, which have at least eight characters and include a combination of letters, numbers, and symbols.

segment.source: These passwords help prevent the compromise of user accounts and administrative accounts by unauthorized users who use manual methods or automated tools to guess weak passwords.
segment.target: These passwords help prevent the compromise of user accounts and administrative accounts by unauthorized users who use manual methods or automated tools to guess weak passwords.

segment.source: Strong passwords that are changed regularly reduce the likelihood of a successful password attack.
segment.target: Strong passwords that are changed regularly reduce the likelihood of a successful password attack.

segment.source: Introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Server 2008, Windows supports fine-grained password policies.
segment.target: Introduced in Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Server 2008, Windows supports fine-grained password policies.

segment.source: This feature provides organizations with a way to define different password and account lockout policies for different sets of users in a domain.
segment.target: This feature provides organizations with a way to define different password and account lockout policies for different sets of users in a domain.

segment.source: Fine-grained password policies apply only to user objects (or inetOrgPerson objects if they are used instead of user objects) and global security groups.
segment.target: Fine-grained password policies apply only to user objects (or inetOrgPerson objects if they are used instead of user objects) and global security groups.

segment.source: To apply a fine-grained password policy to users of an OU, you can use a shadow group.
segment.target: To apply a fine-grained password policy to users of an OU, you can use a shadow group.

segment.source: A shadow group is a global security group that is logically mapped to an OU to enforce a fine-grained password policy.
segment.target: A shadow group is a global security group that is logically mapped to an OU to enforce a fine-grained password policy.

segment.source: You add users of the OU as members of the newly created shadow group and then apply the fine-grained password policy to this shadow group.
segment.target: You add users of the OU as members of the newly created shadow group and then apply the fine-grained password policy to this shadow group.

segment.source: You can create additional shadow groups for other OUs as needed.
segment.target: You can create additional shadow groups for other OUs as needed.

segment.source: If you move a user from one OU to another, you must update the membership of the corresponding shadow groups.
segment.target: If you move a user from one OU to another, you must update the membership of the corresponding shadow groups.

segment.source: Fine-grained password policies include attributes for all the settings that can be defined in the default domain policy (except Kerberos settings) in addition to account lockout settings.
segment.target: Fine-grained password policies include attributes for all the settings that can be defined in the default domain policy (except Kerberos settings) in addition to account lockout settings.

segment.source: When you specify a fine-grained password policy, you must specify all of these settings.
segment.target: When you specify a fine-grained password policy, you must specify all of these settings.

segment.source: By default, only members of the Domain Admins group can set fine-grained password policies.
segment.target: By default, only members of the Domain Admins group can set fine-grained password policies.

segment.source: However, you can also delegate the ability to set these policies to other users.
segment.target: However, you can also delegate the ability to set these policies to other users.

segment.source: The domain must be running at least Windows Server 2008 R2 or Windows Server 2008 to use fine-grained password policies.
segment.target: The domain must be running at least Windows Server 2008 R2 or Windows Server 2008 to use fine-grained password policies.

segment.source: Fine-grained password policies cannot be applied to an organizational unit (OU) directly.
segment.target: Fine-grained password policies cannot be applied to an organizational unit (OU) directly.

segment.source: You can enforce the use of strong passwords through an appropriate password policy.
segment.target: You can enforce the use of strong passwords through an appropriate password policy.

segment.source: There are password policy settings that control the complexity and lifetime of passwords, such as the Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting.
segment.target: There are password policy settings that control the complexity and lifetime of passwords, such as the Passwords must meet complexity requirements policy setting.
